Award.AwardTitle: CDI-Type II: Collaborative Research: Computational Models for Evaluating Long Term CO2 Storage in Saline Aquifers
Award.AbstractNarration: Collaborative Research: Computational Models for Evaluating Long Term<br/>CO2 Storage in Saline Aquifers<br/><br/><br/>The key goal of this project is to produce a prototypical<br/>computational system to accurately predict the fate of injected CO2<br/>in conditions governed by multiphase flow, rock mechanics,<br/>multicomponent transport, thermodynamic phase behavior, chemical<br/>reactions within both the fluid and the rock, and the coupling of all<br/>these phenomena over multiple time and spatial scales.<br/>To tackle this grand challenge effort, a multidisciplinary research<br/>team has been assembled of senior researchers M. F. Wheeler,<br/>T. Arbogast, and M. Delshad of the Center for Subsurface Modeling<br/>and I. Duncan from the Bureau of Economic Geology at The<br/>University of Texas at Austin, as well as M. Parashar of<br/>the Applied Software Systems Laboratory at Rutgers University. This<br/>group has expertise in (1) applied mathematics and computational<br/>science that includes multiscale and multiphysics algorithms, solvers,<br/>uncertainty, and optimization (2) computer science<br/>that includes dynamic adaptivity, model/code couplings, and data<br/>management and transport (3) compositional modeling and<br/>CO2 injection processes and (4) CO2 demonstration sites.<br/>In each of the third and fourth years of the project, we will<br/>host a two-day workshop for high school teachers, advanced high school<br/>students, and undergraduate students with an interest in high school<br/>teaching. We will provide training in the use of a sophisticated groundwater<br/>simulator, to be used as a tool to engage and pique the interest of<br/>high schoolers, perhaps leading some to careers in mathematics, the<br/>sciences, and interdisciplinary work. In addition, two postdoctoral<br/>students and roughly two graduate students will be supported<br/>throughout the project.<br/><br/>Geologic sequestration is a proven means of permanent CO2 greenhouse gas<br/>storage, but it is difficult to design and manage such efforts. Predictive<br/>computational simulation may be the only means to account for the lack of<br/>complete characterization of the subsurface environment, the multiple scales of<br/>the various interacting processes, the large areal extent of saline aquifers,<br/>and the need for long time predictions. This proposal will investigate high<br/>fidelity multiscale and multiphysics algorithms necessary for simulation of<br/>multiphase flow and transport coupled with geochemical reactions and related<br/>mineralogy, and geomechanical deformation in porous media to predict changes in<br/>rock properties during sequestration. The work will result in a prototypical<br/>computational framework with advanced numerical algorithms and underlying<br/>technology for research in CO2 applications, which has been validated and<br/>verified against field-scale experimental tests. The multidisciplinary<br/>research team has expertise in (1) applied mathematics and computational<br/>science, (2) computer science and engineering, (3) compositional modeling and<br/>CO2 injection processes, and (4) CO2 demonstration sites.<br/>In each of the third and fourth years of the project, we will<br/>host a two-day workshop for high school teachers, advanced high school<br/>students, and undergraduate students with an interest in high school<br/>teaching. We will provide training in the use of a sophisticated groundwater<br/>simulator, to be used as a tool to engage and pique the interest of<br/>high schoolers, perhaps leading some to careers in mathematics, the<br/>sciences, and interdisciplinary work. In addition, two postdoctoral<br/>students and roughly two graduate students will be supported<br/>throughout the project.
